Description: Digital photograph (colour); view of engraved, pecked rock art on rock surface showing figures of two antelope, six ostriches two dogs, one unidentified quadruped and two unidentified shapes, all upright and facing left but for top leftmost ostrich. Top (left to right): Two ostriches, another at far top right. Centre (left to right): Dog; unidentified antelope; dog; addax; ostrich; Bottom (left to right): Ostrich with trapping stone attached to leg, ostrich; unidentified quadruped with long tail. 5cm photo scale fitted at base of image. Karkur Talh, Sudan. Scanned
Curator's comments: Trapping stones are large stones used for traps and ties for game and/or cattle which have been used during the last 10,000 years. Karkur Tahl is the largest wadi (dry seasonal riverbed valley) in the sandstone eastern section of Jebel Uweinat, a granite and sandstone massif on the border of Egypt, Libya and Sudan. Karkur Talh is around 25 km long and lies mostly in Sudan, but partly within Egypt’s borders. There is an abundance of both painted and engraved rock art in shelters in the smaller side wadis. The engravings were first revealed to academia by Ahmed Hassanein in 1923 and a few photographs published in his report on the journey in National Geographic in 1924. A more comprehensive publication of rock art sites in Karkur Talh was made by Prince Kemal el Dine with Abbe Breuil in 1925 following his discovery of a painted cave in Karkur Talh. Further exploration and publications were made by numerous others including renowned explorer Ralph Bagnold’s expedition in 1931, with further exploration from László Almásy and Leo Frobenius in 1933. The largest professional exploration of the massif to date was made in 1968 by a team of Belgian scientists.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
